_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.   Facility accidental release and emergency response policy.



  The management and employees of Conserv FS, Inc. are committed to the 

  prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  If an accidental release 

  should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the Marengo Fire Department, 

  McHenry County Local Emergency Planning Committee or other authorities, to mitigate any 

  release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment. 



2. The stationary source and the regulated substances handled.



  The primary activity at the facility,is the storage and distribution of fertilizers for sale to farmers.  

  Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored,and distributed for direct application as a crop 

  production nutrient.  The storage and handling system consists of two storage tanks, 

  loading risers, associated plumbing and nurse tanks.  Access to the site is 

  restricted to authorized facility employees, authorized management personnel and authorized 

  contractors.



3. The worst-case and alternate release scenario.



  This facility has developed a worst-case and alternate-case scenario, however, since this is

  security sensitive information it has been withheld from the Executive Summary as required by

  EPA regulations. 





4. The accidental release prevention program.



  This facility complies with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule and with all applicable 

  state codes and regulations.  This facility has implemented the Compressed 

  Gas Association(CGA's)"American National Standard Safety Requirements for The Storage and 

  Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia"(6th edition),commonly referred to as "ANSI/CGA-2.1 2014

  as adopted by state regulation and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and 

  Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia".  

  Compliance with these regulations and on-going training of our employees make up our 

  a

ccident release prevention program.  



5. Five year accident history. 



  There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that:

 

  - have caused any deaths, injuries, or significant property damage at the facility; nor



  - to our knowledge, have resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, shelter in 

    place, property damage, or environmental damage.



6. The emergency response program.



  The facility is a non-responding facility.  The facility has:



  - a written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard, 29 CFR 1910.38;



  - provided state and local authorities the emergency planning and community right-to-

    know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA).



  - In the event of an emergency involving anhydrous ammonia, it is our policy to notify the 

    Marengo Fire Department and McHenry County LEPC and request that they respond 

    to the emergency.  Our emergency action plans have been coordinated with both the fire 

    department and LEPC.



7. Planned changes to improve safety. 



  Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility.  Periodic evaluations are 

  performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions.  There are no specific safety 

  recommendations for implementation at this time.
